body_html:
Drive by, from someone unaffiliated with the project or company, but concerned about the implications here:

I appreciate the sentiment, but also feel this sort of thing is much too far-reaching, and encroaches too much on the principles of open-source. Many organizations listed in this exclusion fund critical research far removed from warfare--astrophysics, particle physics, aviation, robotics, for ones I can name quickly off the top of my head.

More generally, I think any organization (including Google) can better serve responsible use of AI and ML-enhanced operations in governance and warfare though thought leadership, not carve-outs in a fair use policy. Removing TensorFlow as a (legal) tool for government organizations will not stop AI from being misused by them, and in worst case will cause them to use buggier software lacking the crowdsourced hardening of open-source projects that leads to life-ending mistakes in military applications.

body:
Drive by, from someone unaffiliated with the project or company, but concerned about the implications here:

I appreciate the sentiment, but also feel this sort of thing is much too far-reaching, and encroaches too much on the principles of open-source. Many organizations listed in this exclusion fund critical research far removed from warfare--astrophysics, particle physics, aviation, robotics, for ones I can name quickly off the top of my head.

More generally, I think any organization (including Google) can better serve responsible use of AI and ML-enhanced operations in governance and warfare though thought leadership, not carve-outs in a fair use policy. Removing TensorFlow as a (legal) tool for government organizations will not stop AI from being misused by them, and in worst case will cause them to use buggier software lacking the crowdsourced hardening of open-source projects that leads to life-ending mistakes in military applications.
